messageBody:
I'm afraid I have to disagree with both of you. :)

There is a very good reason to have separate code points and that is
that a character is more than just a glyph or a collection of glyphs.

Separate characters have separate characteristics - especially to dumb
machines.

Since Quikscript and Shavian are phonetic alphabets the sound is the
most obvious and important characteristic.
Combining code points based on glyphs would mean we'd lose that (really,
really, invaluable) information.
What good is a spelling reform if you (or more importantly in this case
the computer) are not sure if a letter is an HUNG or an ING?
Add in ambiguity and you make both Shavian and Quikscript less useful.

I know the obvious answer is that the context of the letter will tell
you whether it's a HUNG or an ING.
But computers are notorious for missing the 'obvious' - how does a
program know what script a given word is in?

You could check all the characters in the document or the sentence or
the word and pick a script based on which are the majority.
But like all 'AI' that approach is going to get it wrong at least some
of the time.

The obvious answer to that is 'you switch fonts/styles/scripts'.
Which is all well and good, except quite often not only can you not
select multiple fonts you can't even select one.
Terminals, XML documents, databases and text boxes are all examples in
which the user has little or no control over the font.

Throwing away all that useful and _correct_ information in favour of
_guessing_ the same information via statistics is not a good idea -
especially if you want to do any sort of reliable data processing.
I think machine readability, especially since it won't actually consume
any additional space is a good reason to keep the glyphs separate.

Obviously none of that applies to characters which are identical in both
alphabets, SHE and SURE, JAY and JUDGE, KEY and KICK, etc.

Sorry for the long email - my fingers run away with me sometimes. :)

Benct Philip Jonsson wrote:
>
> On 29.5.2007 Michael Everson wrote:
>
> > Cyrillic shares very few letterforms with Greek.
>
> Yet contemporary uncial Greek was a proper subset of Old
> Cyrillic. The difference between modern minuscle Greek and
> Cyrillic can after all be argued to be a style difference
> analogous to the case of Greek and Coptic.
>
> This said I think the difference of style argument is
> convincing, and I agree such a difference is lacking in the
> QS/Shavian case.
>
> > Sorry. A case needs to be made to disunify Shavian and QS.
> > So far I haven't seen anything, and reflecting about it
> > and studying so far I don't think it's a credible
> > approach.
>
> The point is not one of graphic design and similarity of
> glyphs, but a political one.
>
> People *think of* them and *want* them as two different
> alphabets, which ought to weigh in. Similarly the difference
> between Hiragana and Katakana could have been handled as
> analogous to the Roman/Italic distinction in Latin (not that
> that would have been a Good Thing), but the Japanese didn't
> want it that way.
>
> Kannada and Telugu come to mind as an analogous case, being
> arguably as much or even more graphically similar than QS
> and Shavian, sharing a common origin and lots of similar
> shapes with similar values. I'll admit there may
> be style differences that might persist in even the most
> progressive typographic expression, but the difference
> between straight and curved matras seem to me of more
> political than practical significance, and the QS/Shavian
> distinction is likewise more political than practical.
>
> We are talking about some forty code points here. Why lump
> them *against the will of the users* when every obscure Han
> character variants used only in ten people's given name gets
> its point?
>
> /BP
>
>
